misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Spreadsheet-style automatic recomputation (variables update downstream results)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once `cost` is defined using `distance_miles`, `milesPerGallon`, and `price_per_gallon`, the value of `cost` will automatically update after those variables later receive user input.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, an assignment like `double cost = (distance_miles / milesPerGallon) * price_per_gallon;` is evaluated immediately, using the current values at that moment. Later changes to `distance_miles`, `milesPerGallon`, and `price_per_gallon` do not “propagate” into `cost`. To use updated inputs, the expression must be computed after reading input, or recomputed/assigned again.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: `cost` is computed before inputs are read, and also risks `NaN` due to `0.0/0.0`.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when variables are assigned values later in the program (through input.nextDouble()), the previously computed expression will automatically recalculate and update to use the new values. They think the cost calculation will retroactively use the values entered after it was computed.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, expressions are evaluated once at the moment they are executed. The cost variable is computed on line 10 when distance_miles, milesPerGallon, and price_per_gallon are all 0. Later assignments to these variables (lines 12-16) do not trigger recalculation of previously assigned expressions. This is fundamentally different from spreadsheet applications like Excel where cells update reactively.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program will print 'The cost of driving is $0.0' (or NaN due to division by zero) instead of the calculated cost based on user input, because the cost is computed before any input is received.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);}

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that defining a variable with a mathematical formula creates a dynamic, permanent relationship where the result variable (cost) will automatically update whenever the source variables (distance_miles, milesPerGallon, price_per_gallon) are modified later in the execution.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student is treating Java assignment like a spreadsheet cell formula rather than an imperative command. In Java, an assignment evaluates the right-hand side expression using the variables' current values at that specific moment in time. Subsequent updates to those variables do not propagate back to update 'cost' unless the assignment statement is explicitly executed again.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Spreadsheet-style auto-updating variables (computed values update themselves later)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they compute `cost` once using variables like `distance_miles`, `milesPerGallon`, and `price_per_gallon`, then after those variables are later filled in from user input, `cost` will “automatically” reflect the new values (like an Excel formula cell updating when referenced cells change).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, an assignment like `double cost = ...;` evaluates the right-hand expression immediately using the *current* values of the variables, and stores that resulting number into `cost`. Later changes to `distance_miles`, `milesPerGallon`, or `price_per_gallon` do not retroactively change `cost`. To use the new inputs, the program must recompute `cost` *after* reading the inputs (or assign to `cost` again).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints `Infinity`/`NaN` or an incorrect constant) because `cost` is computed before inputs are read; also may involve division by zero due to initial values.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Automatic Formula Re-evaluation on Variable Change
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once they define the formula `cost = (distance_miles / milesPerGallon) * price_per_gallon`, this calculation will automatically re-execute and update the `cost` variable whenever any of the input variables are later assigned new values by the user, similar to how spreadsheet cells automatically recalculate when their dependencies change.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variable assignment is a one-time imperative operation that executes sequentially when that line is reached. Once `cost` is assigned a value (in this case, 0/0 = NaN at line 10), it retains that value indefinitely. Simply changing the values of `distance_miles`, `milesPerGallon`, and `price_per_gallon` afterward does not trigger any re-evaluation of previously-executed assignment statements. The student has a reactive mental model (like Excel) when Java actually has a sequential imperative execution model.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program outputs NaN (the result of 0/0) instead of the correct cost. Even though the user enters valid values, the printed cost remains unchanged from when it was calculated with zeros.

evidence.code_snippet: System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that defining a variable with a formula creates a permanent, live link between variables. They expect that when the input variables (distance_miles, milesPerGallon, etc.) are updated later in the code via the Scanner, the 'cost' variable will automatically recalculate its value to reflect those changes, similar to how a cell formula works in a spreadsheet.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand the imperative and sequential nature of Java execution. In Java, an assignment statement evaluates the expression on the right-hand side using the variables' current values at that specific moment in time and stores the result. It does not establish a mathematical dependency or 'listener' that reacts to future state changes.
